response.answer_text: Speaking as someone who most would classify as liberal (though I prefer to think of myself more as pragmatic, pick ’em as I see ‘em) who is anti-religiOSITY, may I offer a few observations? A converse statement, that “the anti-religion crowd is likely to be liberal,” is more likely true. Today’s Conservative will more likely hold quite fundamentalist views also favored by the fundamentally religious. I doubt that it could honestly be said that “most liberals” or even “many liberals” hold anti-religion feelings. I suspect that many liberals, like myself, simply hold little interest in or attention to religion. That’s not the same as holding any animus toward religion. There are LOTS of things that make people happy, and maybe even help them help others and make the world a better place, but that just haven’t sparked MY interest. I know the same holds true with some of my interests holding no value for others. Where I, and liberals, and even conservatives who value consistent beliefs in their lives, where we differ with religiosity — displays of claimed religious value, actions, and attitudes — is where the actions of those claimants clearly belie their protestations of faith and belief in religious principles. The mega-”churches” that ignore biblical teachings against laying up wealth on earth, and instead enrich their pastors tax-free. The “churches” that trample on the rights of their neighbors by flouting zoning ordinances and restrictions. The “churches” and politicians who use each other to get ahead. The “churches” that preach messages of hate. To those who seek to live good, upstanding lives based on ethical and moral principles, whether derived from Jesus Christ or other religious or non-religious teachings, we liberals salute you and wish you all the best.

We don’t. We’re perfectly fine with others practicing their faith and pursuing their own freedom of conscience. Freedom from a state religion, and from the coercion of a state in favor of any faith, was one if the many rallying cries of the American Revolution, after all. Pay homage to Jesus, the Buddha, Moses, Allah, Ganesha, the Four Winds, or Baphomet all you want, or don’t. Enjoy being a private citizen as you pursue enlightenment, and exercise that freedom of conscience that so many have died for. What we despise, however, is when the faithful just don’t seem to be able to grasp that concept. In those cases, the pious are offended because their faith is not considered the fairest of them all, and thus not worthy of special protections and exemptions from the state. “Clearly, the rest of us must hate God!”, they proclaim while clutching their pearls in shock. It is not very persuasive, by the way, when the faithful are intolerant, belligerent, and obnoxious. (See another answer below from a pastor in training who insists that the Leftists - yes, capitalized - are the intolerant ones. Hoo boy.) Conservative Christians, especially evangelicals, are the ones most offended, it seems. Now, it doesn’t help their cause that most of their messages are completely antithetical to Christ’s actual teachings, and that they usually and sadly confuse status (money, celebrity, and power) with morality. (Jesus really was one of those hippies your grandmother warned you about.) What they really hate is the idea that their faith just.. well, just isn’t that special. Sorry, salvation doesn’t confer any special rights and privileges among the rest of us. Not on Earth, anyway. Being saved doesn’t allow anyone to cut in line, or to upgrade their seats to first class without paying, or to super-size at no cost. And it certainly does not mean that the faithful or their faith’s tenets deserve special treatment from the government - or that denying such unwarranted privileges is “persecution”. So no, we don’t “hate religion”. In fact, we believe that everyone who wants it should have it. But honestly, we do get disgusted whenever the self-proclaimed righteous manage to debase themselves.
